awd_titl_txt: Immigration and integration in rural Arctic communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Integration is widely discussed in the context of immigration, yet there have been few studies that explore precisely what integration means to both immigrants and the long-term, native residents. Even less studied is what integration means within rural communities, since immigration rates to these communities typically are not large enough to constitute sites that would be generalizable. In exploring a context  where small, rural communities experience relatively high rates of immigration, this research examines the activities and services that both natives and immigrants incorporate into their communities for integration and analyzes the strengths and weaknesses of those strategies. Data about how both native residents and immigrants identify integration and the best methods to achieve it will advance anthropological science and assist policymakers, social service agencies, and other groups dealing with the effects of immigration into rural areas at local, national, and international levels. Project data and outcomes have the potential to inform and strengthen policies related to immigration.
 
This research involves two three-month-long periods of anthropological fieldwork over three years and takes place in villages within six different rural areas. These villages vary in terms of economic base, population size, history of immigration, and percentage of immigrant population allowing for comparable contexts. The size and social structure of the villages allows for the use of snowball technique to solicit participants, leading to a high percentage of the population being interviewed through both individual and focus group conversations. The research team also conducts participant observation in social interaction venues. Resulting data is analyzed using Grounded Theory and Discourse Analysis methodologies, and outcomes include public presentations, conference papers, publications, and reports to U.S. and Arctic governments.  Results from this research will be useful for people living in small, rural communities, both within and outside the Arctic as they integrate immigrants into their villages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
“Integration” is widely used when discussing the results of people settling in new locations and evaluations of how well or badly integration is proceeding are often reported. However, integration remains a poorly defined term in both academic and public literature, and methods of assessing people's success at achieving integration vary widely. The goal of this study was to explore precisely what both immigrants and long-term, native residents meant when they spoke of integration and to discern activities that they said indicated it was happening.

Our research team was living for three months in rural villages located across five regions of Iceland experiencing high rates of immigration. We collected data through our participation in and observation of activities in public spaces and conducted 362 interviews, with 127 of these with native Icelanders and 235 with immigrants. Attention was paid to activities and services that both natives and immigrants found to be helpful for integration and those that did not result in successful outcomes. Where factors and features that lead to positive outcomes or specific challenges were identified, these were publicized through scholarly and public publications and presentations. In this way, we made available this information about how both native residents and immigrants identify integration and the best methods to achieve it in an attempt to assist politicians, social service agencies, and other groups dealing with the effects of immigration into rural areas at the local, national, and international level in the United States and elsewhere.

Analysis of the data has resulted in several important additions to the literature on immigration to rural areas (see Publications Produced). Close examination of the interviews with those who have chosen to move to them shows that a connection to nature in the location is extremely important but must be paired with a sense of connection to the local social fabric to make residence there fulfilling and an act to which immigrants become committed. Incomers' statements also show that service provision to immigrants is generally as good as it is for long-term residents, though certain sectors, like language education are not meeting their needs. In many ways, this is caused by top-down factors like funding policy, though getting employers to engage with such issues would be another means to counter the problems.

Governmental and civic leaders in small communities, as well as most long-term residents speaking in their individual capacity, desire to incorporate incomers into social networks and activities, but have too few resources to manage this. Greater support from national government and the private concerns that attract most incomers seeking employment, would be extremely beneficial to counter this shortfall. The will is there in most of the locations we examined, but the resources that the rural areas can support are simply not up to meeting the demands and needs of their growing populations.

Ultimately, integration for the vast majority of both long-term residents and immigrants is about becoming active in social groups, forging supportive and reciprocal relations with others in the community, and feeling welcomed by others. The interview and observational data demonstrate that the flow of support and relationship-building clearly needs to run both ways. The receiving community has to take steps to introduce incomers to available resources and open social networks as much as is possible. Long-term residents have to make accommodation for those learning their language and culture and demonstrate interest in learning about the cultural and linguistic practices of those moving into their community. Immigrants need to participate in social groups and events and take advantage of opportunities to become known by long-term residents. 

The results of this study have several broader impacts. As we continue analyzing the data, we expect to find that subtle but important differences will emerge in the ways that various groups of participants identify and define integration. We are just now beginning to examine the data with an eye to see whether and how the economic bases supporting the various communities correlate with variances in peoples' representations of integrative procedures and processes. It is expected that we will find such correlations and that these will cause us to offer different content in proposals for achieving integration to local authorities and community groups in locations reliant primarily on tourism than we will present to those more reliant on agriculture, heavy industry, or fishing. The breadth of data we have gathered also means we will be able to make significant contributions to the literature on immigration, integration, rural demographic change, and socio-environmental interaction. The dynamism of the rural countryside in all nations and the growing numbers of people moving to such locations, both from foreign and domestic points of origin, make research like this extremely important and noteworthy. We appreciate the support provided by the NSF Office of Polar Programs - Arctic Social Sciences unit.
